title: For Sale/Trade:  BEWARE TONS OF SCAMMERS HERE
postcontent:
I have been a armslist regular for over 5 years. Half of them while living in WI and half living here in MN. I have sold, traded and bought many many times and have meet some real good people, most the people on here are honest and legit, but recently the amount of fake and scam ads has risen dramatically and it seems armslist either cannot or will not do anything about the repeat offenders. While some may be ATF or other law enforcement doing some sort of stupid test or sting, most if not all of these ads are just people trying to scam or frustrate others, possibly trying to swing market prices ect.

In the "private party" section here are things to look for-

1.While I know some prefer email most text and call, so if an ad does not have a phone number it could be a scam. If you email your phone number and they either don't reply or reply again by email and not phone, or they don't leave their phone number it's probably a scam.

2.Generic text. Look for copy and paste ads where they just copy the gun manufactures info and paste it in ad. One can tell if a person is actually talking legit in a ad.

3.Real pictures. I know some people don't have good cameras or they are just too lazy but generic pictures are just that, I could post a pic of a tank and say it's mine and for sale. Look for real pictures. In many of the fake ads there is a red background, backgrounds set up to look like actual photographers background are either dealers or scams, many pics are just taken off google images.

4. Willing to meet face to face. If it's ship only it's again either a dealer or a scam. I even had a guy willing to ship to my home knowing I didn't have a ffl or a c&r. In a private sales if they are not willing to meet up they are a scam. As for traveling that is up to a individual person and their schedule but unwilling to do a ftf in a private sale is a for sure warning sign of scam.

5.Too good to be true. Obvious. While some will give a good deal in a trade and maybe just need the cash bad if one knows firearms prices they know is real and what is scam.

6.The no reply or stupid reply. Many scam artists don't even reply because they have so many scams going they can't get to all of them. Then there are some that will send messages like "Waiting on you response" or "are we going to deal?" If these are then type of responses you get after you send a valid question or pry for more info it's a scam.

7.No trade. While many just want to sell and many legit sellers post "no trades" I have seen a trend lately of scam ads using this language. It has to do with the fact there is no way to scam in a trade as the scam is to get you to send money. Anyone not interested in a good trade I really have to wonder. But this is the least of the warnings as again many only want to sell and there is a sale/trade option but then again many don't even know that title option is there.

Hope this helps some. I just couldn't sit by anymore and not post a response to the numerous fake and scam ads up this past week and longer. I know for a fact the Ed Brown 1911 up just today is a scam. So they are not going away.
Price of help is FREE.

(Mfg by Fémáru Fegyver és Gépgyár, Budapest)

Caliber: ....................... 7.92 x 57mmJS (8mm Mauser)
Muzzle Velocity: ........... 780 m/sec with issue JS ball cartridge
Rifling: ........................ concentric 4 groove, 1 turn in 10 in. (Right Hand Twist)

Qty Mfg: ...................... 140,000; 33,003 made in 1941 (approximately).

Source: ........................ "Bolt Action Rifles" Expanded 4th Ed., by Frank de Haas and Dr. Wayne van Zwoll, pp.51-55 ; Gunboards.com reference from Hungarian military historian Lorand Dombrady re: Qty Mfg. ; Mannlicher Infantry Rifles Hungary

1941 Code jhv G98/40 Infantry Rifle 


The Mannlicher Gew.98/40 German Infantry Rifle was known by the Germans as the Infanterie Gewehre G98/40.

These German contract guns were made from 1941 to 1944 by Fémáru Fegyver és Gépgyár, Budapest, (German Ordnance code “jhv”), with some or all of the work possibly subcontracted to Danuvia Gépgyár, Budapest (German Ordnance code “jua”). 

The Hungarian-made G98/40 is not a mauser, and shares nothing significant with the G98, rather it is a mannlicher-based receiver design patterned after the Hungarian 35M, the only firearm ever purpose-built for the 8x56R cartridge. The G98/40 was contracted as a war-expedient, to exploit the existing 35M tooling. They were issued primarily to the Luftwaffe.

Distinguishing features of the G98/40 include:

- mannlicher-based receiver design with all steel parts blued;
- two-piece bolt with detachable bolt-heads, and bolt handle positonned ahead of the receiver bridge;
- chambered in 8x57;
- two-piece stock system (similar to that found on the Lee Enfield). Early stocks were walnut, later laminate; and
- mauser sling, bayonet and staggered row magazine designs, allowing the use of the K98 sling, bayonet and stripper clips.

G98/40 infantry rifles are among the rarest Third Reich infantry rifles a collector is likely to encounter and should be recognized and purchased at any opportunity, if possible. Available numbers of examples today indicate that either very few rifles survived the war, or the countries who may still have them aren't releasing them for sale at this time.

Manufactured in 1941:  Serial number 6164
